results.abstract: article discusses impact of Watergate scandal on corps, which are now fearful of making pol contributions and wondering how else they can influence politicians if not by contributions; cartoon (National Econ Survey article) (L)

headline.main: Watergate Raises New Problems of Giving and Getting for Businessmen

results.snippet: For many of the nation's businessmen, the spreading stain of Watergate has created a host of problems that must be resolved in 1974. The spectacle of eight bluechip corporations admitting in court that they had illegally contributed hundreds of...
results.lead_paragraph: For many of the nation's businessmen, the spreading stain of Watergate has created a host of problems that must be resolved in 1974. The spectacle of eight bluechip corporations admitting in court that they had illegally contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars in company funds to President Nixon's re-election has chipped away at business's already eroded image.

results.abstract: Cleveland (Ohio) Mayor Ralph J Perk, Repub, appears to be candidate for US Sen in '74; urged Gov John J Gilligan during wk of Dec 31 not to name Howard M Metzenbaum as Sen to fill seat vacated by Atty Gen-designate William B Saxbe because of Metzenbaum's dispute with IRS; statement excerpt; Perk stressed statement was not declaration of candidacy on his part; Metzenbaum, who was sworn in as Sen on Jan 4, and former astronaut John H Glenn Jr are declared candidates for Dem Sen nomination; Lt Gov John W Brown is only announced Repub candidate at present; local Repub leaders believe Perk would be strong statewide candidate and are urging him to run for Sen; Perk declines to comment on his plans (M)

headline.main: Republican Mayor of Cleveland Sounding Like Senate Candidate; Opposed by Astronaut

results.snippet: Despite his protestations to the contrary, Mayor Ralph J. Perk is sounding more and more like a candidate for the United States Senate.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Despite his protestations to the contrary, Mayor Ralph J. Perk is sounding more and more like a candidate for the United States Senate.

results.abstract: Ex-astronaut Edgar D Mitchell article on extrasensory-perception experiment he performed during Apollo 14 lunar expedition says evidence of psychic research suggests that mind may be able to operate independently of body; says death may simply be alteration in consciousness, transition for continued life in nonmaterial form; says such research puts scientific world in position where it appears that basic concept of man and universe must be revised to some degree (M)
results.snippet: PALO ALTO, Calif.-During the Apollo. 14 lunar expedition, I performed an extrasensory-perception experiment-the world's first in space. In it five symbols-a star, cross, circle, wavy line and square--were oriented randomly in columns of 25. Four...
results.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.-During the Apollo. 14 lunar expedition, I performed an extrasensory-perception experiment-the world's first in space. In it five symbols-a star, cross, circle, wavy line and square--were oriented randomly in columns of 25. Four persons in the United States attempted to guess the order of the symbols.

results.snippet: Surrounded by a red curtain, a dozen prize beef cattle were standing in straw, their rumps resembling an offensive line poised for a play. On the sawdust floor of the Astrodome, 25 bartenders were pouring drinks.

headline.main: Perk of Ohio to Seek Senate Seat; Notes on People

results.snippet: The Mayor of Cleveland, Ralph J. Perk, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate. State party leaders indicated they expected Mr. Perk to have little or no opposition.
results.lead_paragraph: The Mayor of Cleveland, Ralph J. Perk, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate. State party leaders indicated they expected Mr. Perk to have little or no opposition.

results.abstract: US Dist Judge Barrington D Parker, in decision creating problem for officials of Fed agencies that license indus to use Govt-owned inventions, declares unconst the granting of exclusive licenses without Cong approval and has voided GSA licensing regulations; GSA states that it is recommending to Justice Dept that case be appealed; decision is rendered in action brought against GSA by Public Citizen Inc, Ralph Nader orgn; NASA and AEC are not affected by order as they operate under special laws; illus of astronaut Joseph P Kerwin wearing cap of material patented by NASA (L)

results.lead_paragraph: Officials of the Federal agencies that license industry to use Government-owned inventions have a new problem: a judge in United States District Court here has declared unconstitutional the granting of exclusive licenses without Congressional approval and has voided the licensing regulations of the General Services Administration. Soviet Is Thought to Modify Craft to Let Its Astronauts Maneuver; Justifies Use of Men

results.snippet: In preparation for the planned orbital docking of Soviet and American spacecraft next year, the Soviet Union is believed to be modifying its Soyuz craft to enable the astronauts on board to function more as pilots than as passengers.
results.lead_paragraph: In preparation for the planned orbital docking of Soviet and American spacecraft next year, the Soviet Union is believed to be modifying its Soyuz craft to enable the astronauts on board to function more as pilots than as passengers.

headline.main: Soviet Is Thought to Modify Craft to Let Its Astronauts Maneuver

results.snippet: In preparation for the planned orbital docking of Soviet and American spacecraft next year, the Soviet Union is believed to be modifying its Soyuz craft to enable the astronauts on board to function more as pilots than as passengers. Nevertheless, on...
results.lead_paragraph: In preparation for the planned orbital docking of Soviet and American spacecraft next year, the Soviet Union is believed to be modifying its Soyuz craft to enable the astronauts on board to function more as pilots than as passengers. Nevertheless, on the basis of details of the Soyuz design and operation that have become known, the Soviet craft apparently has far more limited capabilities than the elaborate Apollo spacecraft the Americans will use.
